'''José Zabala-Santos''' (sometimes spelled as '''Jose Zabala Santos'''<ref name=Lambiek/>) (20 July 1911 – September 7, 1985),<ref name=Anima/> nicknamed as '''"Mang Pepe"''' ("Mister Pepe" in the [[Tagalog language]]<ref name=Bansa>Definition of [http://www.bansa.org/dictionaries/tgl/?dict_lang=tgl&type=search&data=Mang ''Mang''], bansa.org</ref>) by hometown neighbors<ref name=Anima/> and as '''"Zabala"''' by colleagues in the cartooning profession,<ref name=Lambiek/><ref name=Anima/> was a successful cartoonist in the [[Philippines]]<ref name=Lambiek/> and was one of the pioneers of [[Philippine comics]].<ref name=UPEd/> He became one of the most popular cartoonists in the Philippines during the 1950s because of his cartoon characters such ''Popoy'', ''Sianong Sano'', and ''Lukas Malakas''.<ref name=Comic>[http://www.comicartfans.com/gallerypiece.asp?piece=533816&gsub=84321 Sianong Sano by Jose Zabala Santos 1950's]. Comicartfans.com (2009-07-07). Retrieved on 2011-05-25.</ref> Zabala is one of the "respected names" of artists in the [[Philippine cartoon]] and comics industry.<ref name=Council/>
==Biography== Although born in [[Calumpit]], [[Bulacan]], Philippines in 1911, Zabala spent his childhood years in [[Malabon|Malabon, Rizal]].<ref name=Lambiek/> He was a resident of Kuatro Kantos, Malabon.<ref name=Anima/> He first learned how to draw through his mother, a painter.<ref name=Anima/>
===Education=== He attended college at the School of Fine Arts of the [[University of the Philippines]], where he met [[Francisco Reyes (comic book illustrator)|Francisco Reyes]], another Philippine comics pioneer.<ref name=Lambiek/> However, he quit school when he was 16 years old. One of the reasons is that the UP School of Fine Arts was not offering cartooning classes<ref name=Anima/> He instead opted to enroll and earned a diploma in a cartooning course offered in the [[United States]] via [[correspondence learning]].<ref name=Anima/>
===Career=== Zabala officially started his cartooning career in 1932 through the sponsorship of [[Amado V. Hernandez]], who was then the editor of Sampaguita magazine. It was during this time that he created the characters ''Titina'', ''Lukas Malakas'', and ''Popoy''.<ref name=Anima/> After the demise of Sampaguita magazine, Zabala moved to [[Liwayway]] Publications,<ref name=Anima/> where he created the cartoon character name ''Sianong Sano'' in 1935 for the Tagalog-language magazine ''Liwayway''. Through Liwayway, Zabala's ''Lukas Malakas'' became popular.<ref name=Anima/>
Although popularized by [[Larry Alcala]] – one of Zabala's students – Zabala was the original creator of the so-called ''Slice of Life'' cartoon page.<ref name=Anima/> Zabala's version of "Slice of Life" is titled ''Lifestyle''.<ref name=Lifestyle>[http://romiworks.multiply.com/journal/item/23/Zabala_Santos_at_Malang_komiks Jose Zabala Santos' Lifestyle (1979)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110826085518/http://romiworks.multiply.com/journal/item/23/Zabala_Santos_at_Malang_komiks |date=2011-08-26 }}. Romiworks.multiply.com. Retrieved on 2011-05-25.</ref> He temporarily interrupted his cartooning career in 1941 upon the onset of [[World War II]].<ref name=Anima/> From 1942 to 1948, he worked for the art department of the Manalang Advertising Agency.<ref name=Anima/> It was in the advertising field where Zabala became interested in the art of [[animation]].<ref name=Anima/> After World War II, Zabala moved to Halakhak Komiks to create ''Pinoy'', a cartoon character that had similarities to his ''Popoy'' character in Liwayway magazine. He also illustrated comic book covers while working for Halakhak Komiks.<ref name=Lambiek/> Zabala's ''Si Pino'' was one of the comic strips featured in the first issue of Halakhak Komiks.<ref name=Komiklopedia>[http://komiklopedia.wordpress.com/2007/04/03/halakhak-komiks-1946-1947/ Halakhak Komiks by Komiklopedia on 2007/04/03]. Komiklopedia.wordpress.com (1929-01-11). Retrieved on 2011-05-25.</ref>
After the declaration of [[Martial Law in the Philippines]] in 1972, Zabala retired from his cartooning career in Philippine comics to work instead for the [[Philippine Manufacturing Company]] (PMC, now known as [[Procter & Gamble]])<ref name=Lambiek>[http://www.lambiek.net/artists/z/zabala-santos_jose.htm Jose Zabala-Santos (Mang Pepe) (20/7/1911 – 7/9/1985, The Philippines)]. Lambiek.net. Retrieved on 2011-05-25.</ref> in 1949.<ref name=Anima/> In 1955, Zabala worked on an animation project entitled [[Juan Tamad]] (“Lazy John” or “John the Lazy”) in cooperation with Francisco Reyes. While working at the Philippine Manufacturing Company, Zabala shot and produced a six-minute 35-mm animated short film for a product of the company. However, there was no certainty whether the film that was processed in the United States had actually been presented as a commercial.<ref name=Council>[http://www.animationcouncil.org/news.php?p=140 Animation Council of the Philippines honors Zabala] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110727090835/http://www.animationcouncil.org/news.php?p=140 |date=2011-07-27 }}. Animationcouncil.org. Retrieved on 2011-05-25.</ref>
In 1970, Zabala retired from the Philippine Manufacturing Company in order to join the advertising agency of [[Francisco Reyes (illustrator)|Francisco Reyes]], another Filipino pioneer in comics.<ref name=Anima/> In 1978, Zabala joined his nephew [[Nonoy Marcelo]], also a cartoonist<ref name=UPEd>[http://www.up.edu.ph/oldforum/2002/Nov-Dec02/ptyk.html Ptyk is home By Alicor Panao] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110102140958/http://www.up.edu.ph/oldforum/2002/Nov-Dec02/ptyk.html |date=2011-01-02 }}. Up.edu.ph (2002-12-19). Retrieved on 2011-05-25.</ref> to work on the production of ''[[Tadhana]]'' ("Fate"), a full-length [[Filipino cartoon and animation|animation]] project.<ref name=Anima/>
===Death=== Zabala died in 1985 at the age of 74.<ref name=Anima>[http://www.animahenasyon.com/2009/62/Jose-Zabala-Santos Philippine Animation Festival » 2009 » Lifetime Achievement Awardee » Jose Zabala Santos] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110904023047/http://www.animahenasyon.com/2009/62/Jose-Zabala-Santos |date=2011-09-04 }}. Animahenasyon. Retrieved on 2011-05-25.</ref>
==Awards== Zabala received honors and recognitions for his contribution to the Philippine comics and magazine industry. His awards included the Komiks Operation Brotherhood (KOMOPEB) Life Achievement Award (1984) and the 4th Gintong Parangal ng Malabon's Gawad ng Katangian (1984).<ref name=Anima/> Zabala was posthumously awarded the Lifetime Achievement Award by the [[Animation Council of the Philippines, Inc.]] (ACPI) during the November 25 to 28, 2009 Animahenasyon Pinoy Animation Festival that was held at the Gateway Mall, [[Araneta Center]], [[Cubao]], [[Quezon City]].<ref name=Council/>
